case_name: Bombay Municipal Corporation and the Municipal Commissioner of Bombay v. the owners of 41 final plots Nos. 106 to 116 and 118 to 147 under the Bombay Town Planning Scheme, Santacruz VI

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 1121 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1121 of 1970.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 24, 1969 of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 2 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 24, 1969 of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 2 of 1967.

facts.text: High Court order dated 24th April, 1969 substantially confirming the order passed by a single Judge in Writ Petition No. 474 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: confirming the order passed by a single Judge of that Court in Writ Petition No. 474 of 1965.

facts.text: Appellants are the Bombay Municipal Corporation and the Municipal Commissioner of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants before this Court are the Bombay Municipal Corporation and the Municipal Commissioner of Bombay, and the respondents are the owners

facts.text: Respondents are the owners of 41 final plots Nos. 106 to 116 and 118 to 147 under the Bombay Town Planning Scheme, Santacruz VI.

anchor.surface_text: of 41 final plots Nos. 106 to 116 and 118 to 147 under the Bombay Town Planning Scheme, Santacruz VI.

facts.text: Bandra Municipal Committee by resolution dated 15th June, 1948 declared intention to frame Town Planning Scheme under section 9 of Town Planning Act, 1915.

anchor.surface_text: That Committee, by a resolution dated 15th June, 1948, declared its intention to frame a Town Planning Scheme under section 9 1  of the Town Planning Act,

facts.text: Bandra Municipal Committee abolished and area absorbed within limits of Bombay Municipal Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Municipal Committee was abolished and the area of that municipality was absorbed within the limits of the Bombay Municipal Corporation.

facts.text: Government of Bombay sanctioned making of the Scheme on 7th May, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: applied to the Government, and on 7th May, 1951, the Government of Bombay sanctioned the making of the Scheme.

facts.text: Draft scheme prepared and published on 30th April, 1963 and sanctioned on 6th May, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On 30th April, 1963, a draft scheme was, prepared and published as required by the Act and it was duly sanctioned by the Government on 6th May, 1954.

facts.text: Arbitrator appointed on 17th August, 1954 to finalize the scheme.

anchor.surface_text: On 17th August, 1954, an Arbitrator was appointed to finalize the scheme and the Arbitrator formulated the final Scheme

facts.text: Town Planning Act, 1954 came into force on 1st April, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the Town Planning Act, 1915 was replaced by the Town Planning Act, 1954 which came into force on 1st April, 1957.

facts.text: Final Scheme sanctioned by Government on 21st August, 1958 and came into force from 1st January, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Finally, on 21st August, 1958, the final Scheme was sanctioned by the Government which directed that the Scheme should companye into force from 1st January, 1959.

facts.text: Scheme known as Bombay Town Planning Scheme, Santacruz No. VI covered area of about 160 acres divided by Chodbunder Road; concerned with eastern part of about 54 acres.

anchor.surface_text: The Scheme, as already stated, was known as the Bombay Town Planning Scheme, Santacruz No. VI and companyered an area .of about 160 acres divided into two parts by the Chodbunder Road

facts.text: Part of area belonged to N. J. Wadia Trust; Receiver appointed on 8th February, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: A part of this area belonged to the N. J. Wadia Trust. In a Trust Petition made to the High Court, a Receiver was appointed on 8th February. 1948

facts.text: Unauthorised huts, sheds and stables built in the area which was full of slums; removal one object of Scheme.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that unauthorised huts, sheds and stables had been built in this area and the whole of it was full of slums, the removal of which was one of the objects

facts.text: Receiver transferred total area of 69,625 sq. yards comprised in 41 final plots Nos. 106 to 116 and 118 to 147 to respondents 1 to 3 and one Cardi on 31st July, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On 31st July, 1962, the Receiver transferred a total area of 69,625 sq. yards companyprised in 41 final plots being Nos. 106 to 116 and 118 to 147 to respondents 1 to 3

facts.text: Cardi sold his plots to respondents 4 and 5.

anchor.surface_text: Cardi sold his plots in due companyrse to respondents 4 and 5.

facts.text: Scheme came into force on 1st January, 1959; period of 2 to 3 years allowed for implementation but no action taken by Corporation due to resistance by slum-dwellers.

anchor.surface_text: As already numbered, the Scheme came into force on 1st January, 1959 and, though, under the Scheme, a period of 2 to 3 years had been allowed for the purpose

facts.text: Respondents called upon Corporation to implement Scheme by removing slums etc. and provide roads and drains but Corporation remained inactive.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, from whom the betterment charges, etc. were being recovered by the Corporation, called upon the Corporation to implement the Scheme

facts.text: Respondents 1 to 3 filed Writ Petition No. 474 of 1965 on 13th October, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: hence, respondents 1 to 3 filed Writ Petition No. 474 of 1965 on the Original Side of the High Court on 13th October, 1965.

facts.text: Writ petition prayed for mandamus directing appellants to construct roads and drains as per Scheme and remove huts, sheds etc. from 41 plots.

anchor.surface_text: By this petition, respondents 1-3 prayed to the Court  1  to issue a writ of mandamus or a writ in the nature of mandamus against the appellants directing them

facts.text: Single Judge held primary responsibility of Corporation to implement Scheme and granted writs substantially as prayed.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge held that, under the Town Planning Act and the Scheme, it was the primary responsibility of the Corporation, which was the local authority,

facts.text: Appellate Bench of High Court confirmed single Judge order with minor variations.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal, the Appellate Bench of the High Court companyfirmed the order of the learned Judge with only minor variations.

facts.text: Attorney-General did not dispute primary obligation of Corporation to provide roads and drains per Scheme and remove unauthorised structures on public purpose land.

facts.text: Respondents' counsel clarified relief sought in terms of section 55 for structures contravening Scheme.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Corporation bound to remove structures contravening Town Planning Scheme even on private plots.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Corporation is so bound.

facts.text: Till 1964 nothing done by Corporation to implement Scheme; respondents served notices but Corporation stalled.

anchor.surface_text: The Scheme came into force in 1959 and it is an admitted fact that, till 1964, numberhing at all was done by the Corporation to implement the Scheme.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal with modification to writ: remove structures contravening Scheme within one year from judgment date.

issues.text: whether the Municipal Corporation, as the local authority under the Act owed a duty to remove the unauthorised structures, even though those structures were on private final plots of the respondents

anchor.surface_text: The point of substance in this appeal is whether the Municipal Corporation, as the local authority under the Act owed a duty to remove the unauthorised structure, even though those structures were on private final plots of the respondents.

arguments.claim: Regulation 6 prohibits huts, sheds etc. within the Scheme area

arguments.claim: Final Scheme has effect as if enacted in the Act per s.51(3)

anchor.surface_text: Such is the importance of the Final Scheme as sanctioned by the Government that, under s. 51(3), the Town Planning Scheme has the same effect as if it were enacted in the Act.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the Corporation is so bound.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Corporation is so bound. It is not necessary to go through the several provisions of the Town Planning Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Local authority empowered under s.55(1)(a) to remove any contravening building or work in scheme area regardless of private ownership; ss.53-55 read together impose this duty.

holdings.text: There can be no doubt that the Corporation, as the local authority, is wholly responsible for the preparation and implementation of every development plan.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that the Corporation, as the local authority, is wholly responsible for the preparation and implementation of every development plan. The preamble shows that the Town Planning Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preamble purpose and ss.3,12,18 require local authority to prepare and execute development plans and schemes effectively.

holdings.text: The whole scheme of the Act, therefore, and especially sections 53 to 55 leave no doubt that it is the primary duty of the local authority to remove all such buildings and works in the whole of the area which contravene the Town Planning Scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The whole scheme of the Act, therefore, and especially sections 53 to 55 leave no doubt that it is the primary duty of the local authority to remove all such buildings and works in the whole of the area which contravene the Town Planning Scheme.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ss.53 vests lands, determines rights; s.54 evicts unauthorized occupants; s.55 explicitly authorizes removal of contravening works anywhere in scheme area; costs recoverable.

holdings.text: The Scheme and the regulations made thereunder must be read as supplemental to the Act and, when that is done, there is no room for any doubt whatsoever that the local authority is entirely responsible for removing the huts, sheds, stables and other temporary structures which contravene the Town Planning Scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The Scheme and the regulations made thereunder must be read as supplemental to the Act and, when that is done, there is no room for any doubt whatsoever that the local authority is entirely responsible for removing the huts,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.51(3) gives scheme force of law; Note 11 requires removal of non-conforming structures within 1 year; Regulation 6 prohibits such structures; integrates with s.55.

holdings.text: It has been long held that, where a statute imposes a duty the performance or non-performance of which is not a matter of discretion, a mandamus may be granted.

anchor.surface_text: It has been long held that, where a statute imposes a duty the performance or non-performance of which is not a matter of discretion, a mandamus may be granted ordering that to be done which the statute requires to be done.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent (Halsbury); statutory duty under Act is mandatory, not discretionary; court discretion not withheld as no unclean hands or delay by respondents.

holdings.text: We do not, therefore, think any adequate reasons have been given for refusing the writ.

anchor.surface_text: The Scheme came into force in 1959 and it is an admitted fact that, till 1964, nothing at all was done by the Corporation to implement the Scheme. ... We do not, therefore, think any adequate reasons have been given for refusing the writ.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory bar for owners collecting rent; Corporation solely delayed implementation; respondents pursued remedies appropriately.

holdings.text: In our opinion, therefore, there is nothing in the new Act which requires us to reconsider the above finding.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, there is nothing in the new Act which requires us to reconsider the above finding. It is clear, therefore, on a consideration of the provisions of the Bombay Town Planning Act, 1954

holdings.reasoning_summary: Maharashtra Act 1966 ss.88-90 correspond to old ss.53-55 without altering duties; old schemes deemed continued.

precedents.citation: The Queen v. The Church Wardens of All Saints, Wigan and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: It is pointed out by Lord Hatherley in The Queen v. The Church Wardens of All Saints, Wigan and Others 1 , that upon a prerogative writ there may arise many matters of discretion which may induce the Judges to withhold the grant of it- matters c

precedents.case_name: The Queen v The Church Wardens of All Saints, Wigan and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: upon a prerogative writ there may arise many matters of discretion which may induce the Judges to withhold the grant of it- matters connected with delay, or possibly with the conduct of the parties but, when the Judges have exercised their discretion in directing that which is in itself lawful to be done, no other Court can question that discretion
precedents.cited_holding: when the Judges have exercised their discretion in directing that which is in itself lawful to be done, no other Court can question that discretion in so directing
